gCHoPPR6tw088llSVuuIsw.text: Ehhh, an okay burrito place for London.   Pork was okay, juicy, but the overall presentation of the burrito was not good at all.  They stuffed tons of rice, beans and veggies in my burrito disproportionate to the meat, AND the burrito was falling apart as I ate it (and yes I did eat it using the proper peel aluminum foil down as you go technique)

hR1N6n2iPGIdv3KHsOzkoA.text: Chilango's prove that it's actually possible to have good, cheap mexican on this side of the ocean.  I'm pretty picky about my mexican too! I love that they will let you mix whatever you want, my fav it both the steak and pork.  I have eaten here so many times the staff actually remember me.  But for £10 I can get an awesome frozen rita and a hot n spicy dinner.  Total winner in my book!  Awesome side note:  they will make a frozen rita to-go!! MARRY ME CHILIAGO!

mKVZqjsqcxDHNVm7G7ZH-A.text: In my never ending hunt for good Mexican food in London, I came to Chilango in Angel on a whim. Happened to be walking by, there was an employee standing outside offering crisps and salsa, so I sampled. Seemed good and decided to give the place a try. Two tacos, a burrito and a bag of crisps, I was sold. Chilango makes my list of Mexican places that I actually like. So far, it is only rivaled by one other place (Wahaca). The service was quick and friendly and they make everything to order, right in front of you! My only complaint was that regardless how good their salsas and guacamole are, the crisps I had were extremely stale. Wasn't sure what to think when they gave them out in a pre-packaged bag. However, they fully redeemed their selves by having Pacifico available, which is my absolute favorite Mexican beer.

e8mhDy5GnKcRlXaUJq2pjg.text: Great Burritos, I doubled the meat, added guacamole and had every side possible and the fella serving still managed to roll it up. Fair play. Tasty, reasonably priced and filling, for a fast food type bite on Upper Street it's definitely the place to stop.

0U2kBx69tf0JONK2lX9ncA.text: It's only been a couple days since I've moved to London, but I'm already craving Mexican food.  To that end, I did a little research and decided to go to Chilango's.  It's basically a repackaged Chipotle, which is fine by me.  There aren't a ton of options, but it's serviceable.  The food's decent, though it seemed like my steak had been sitting in the tray for a little while.  Servers were nice enough, too.  All in all, it was all right, but nothing more.

Jmemsv_sxRtolc5lb9iUow.text: This used to be one of my favourite burrito places in London. Until I discovered that my all time favourite Chipotle has opened 5 locations across London. One of the just across the street from Chilango. There are many pluses for Chilango, but in terms of flavour there's no comparison! I'm sorry Chilango

5QOhZpfDiLo5WkbCe5dAxg.text: As a lover of East LA Mexican food, I have tried many of the burrito bars that seem to have popped up in London but this one just seems to hit the button, and at the right price. I went there on the way home this evening to grab a bite and it was as good as ever, even if they HAVE put the guacamole up to £1 extra....I'm pregnant now so cant drink but am DYING for their frozen magheritas, the first time I've seen it so accessible in London The last one I had was in NYC...

ov6WmYCVZ5yKarV1YuHfvg.text: I'm a huge fan of Chilango, but sadly live right at the opposite end of London so rarely get to visit. Having tried brands like Chipotle in the US it was about time that the UK got an equivalent. Chilango does amazing burritos made with fresh ingredients. Walking down a conveyor belt system, you get to choose how your burrito is made from the type of chilli sauce, to whether you want added extras like guacamole. The burritos are stuffed full and eating them can get quite messy, but then that's all part of the fun! The place is licensed so you can choose to have Mexican beer and margaritas with you meal, but the bottomless hibiscus juice is equally tempting.

IixcCGR2ms04XSxd3KeDYQ.text: So, after having been to ample restaurants I am still venturing through the city trying to find good Mexican food that compares to California food and Chilango is pretty close. They have great veggie options and their guacamole is amazing! The restaurant also has a nice atmosphere for a fast food place more or less. I will definitely go here again! The reason why I am taking a point off is because they have no fish options and it's simply not as good as in the US, but it's pretty close!

xgWyWyOonRUD_SOMtmNegA.text: Surprisingly...not awful. In fact, actually pretty good. I was initially turned off by the shiny bright Alice-in-neon-anime-wonderland colors since I'm used to a style of taqueria that's basically the grimier and dirtier the tastier and the more likely to be open at 2am to stumble after a drunken Mission bar hopping bender. Those neon pinks and greens would burn your eyes out after a bleary night of tequila shots and the smiling people behind the counter might give you the evil eye if you pass out with your face in a bowl of tortilla chips. Not that I would ever do that. However, after sampling a marinated pork burrito, I'm pleasantly happy with the outcome. We waited for the sauteed veggies to be cooked up fresh, so I stood and eyed the tins of food for a while. I was tempted by the actual pinkness in the medium-rare steak but ended up going for the really good quality pork, which was soft and tender if not impressively flavorful. I noticed real hand-mashed Haas guacamole with avocado chunks (not the pureed green mushy-peas-esque drivel from some other spots), and enjoyed an actually lip-tingling spicy green salsa as well.  Cilantro rice, sour cream, good cheese, salsa fresca and a steamed tortilla all melded quite well in my book.I'd like to give 3.5 stars, since I think I gave El Burrito 3 and this was waayyy better. But hey, I'm a fan. Chilango, you're just a little too shiny but your food is an enjoyable surprise.

drC42-A8MJet7zLCMRB21w.text: Think of this as the Subway of Tex-Mex. You pick the ingredients you want in your burrito/taco, and people make it for you. It's a production line type deal. That said, Chilango probably make the best burrito I've had in London. I like how they've got the multiple flavour thing going on in their food, what with the marinated meat (veggie options too), choices of beans (pinto or black), salsas (mild -hot), options of salads and guacamole (how can you not include it?). They are licensed so you get to have your Modelo Especial with your meal, which is pretty cool, I thought. They've designed the place quite interestingly. Kind of "hip" Mexican, playing off that wrestling type theme. I should stress that this is doesn't compare to the likes of Mestizo or Mercado, two proper Mexican restaurants (where you'd better NOT be ordering a burrito!), but it does Tex-Mex fantastically. Pros- great tasting food- licensed- nicely designed- better than Mexi-Cali to my tastebuds Cons- is a chain store (so much for supporting independent stores)- bit more pricey than similar type Tex-Mex's (Mexicali)

Vea3bsQmAq1iC6xjTSC4qw.text: Really good food here, fresh produce, meat is nicely marinated. I crave their burritos. So many reviewers are comparing it to the U.S. mexican food, this is the U.K. When not comparing, it's actually really good food & value.

0--Hrzm3Ah-LzES-XtSWLw.text: There was a big problem with the Burrito-eating contest: I got into about my second big bite and realised, wow, this is actually an extremely delicious burrito. This distracted me somewhat. The lovely mix of spicy chicken, sour creme, black beans and fluffy rice being far too enjoyable to simply engulf without any hint of contemplative appreciation. I especially love how, unless extremely skilled in wrapping, there's always just that annoying trickle of delicious sauce that you just can't stop leaking out. Then at the end the whole thing loses integrity and you just make a big mess. But that's the fun of it, right? That's actually the perfect burrito, right?

X3-p6P1ZAvC0S08NoRdsnA.text: My first experience of this place was last night at their charity event and Burrito eating contest. Located right next Angel tube station, Chilango's coudlnt be more convient and funky.but i am alittle biased i supposed, because I WON THE CONTEST!!!! Regardless, the burrito was huge and very tasty and the staff were incredibly friendly. As i remarked to the owner after winning im prouder of this momement that i am of graduating from Uni well there were alot more people chanting my name. I will be returning shortly and spending my time with the next burrito and giving the time and attention it deserves.

JW4zkYZZZHK9VKnNMoy4yA.text: oh London, if this is the best mexican food you have to offer, then I feel bad, bad, bad for you.  this is basically a clone of Chipotle, down to the salsa and hot sauce options.While it isn't bad per se, and I'd normally give it 3 stars, it loses a star for failing to live up to the hype.

Nn6TU5TP9Tg_a194TQsXGg.text: Despite being in Angel this place is actually great.  Conveyor belt Mexican food which is cheap as hell and tasty.  Probably the best burrito I have had in London (which admittedly isn't like saying the best foie gras in France but still...).I am already excited about another pulled pork burrito. Hella yeah.

lpsKXwk9OVipOk8fTT1x0A.text: Best burrito in town and cheap

SjLaDfUZ44-FkatfxHVE0A.text: The chilango contest two weeks ago, as part of a Qype Event, permitted to myself to win a 90 meals voucher! So since one week, I had the occasion to go in this amazing mexican restaurant a lot of time. I try to test different meal each time, burritos chicken or meat, with guacamole or without, some tacos or salad, and I swear, everything is absolutely delicious, fresh and tasty! In my opinion the best one is the famous Chicken Burrito without beans, but with guacamole. I do not want to say more, you just have to try it! Maybe I will see you there because with my voucher, I will finish to sleep just in front of the restaurant, during three month, and next time I will probably win the chilango contest ;-)

bnV9Cc-Jygeo4lLkupO8iA.text: Dropped in there tonight as I was in Islington for work reasons  very glad I did. Had a very nice, good sized veggie burrito, with hot salsa and extra hot sauce  and was pleasantly surprised that it was actually really good and spicy. Very smiley staff too  which makes a difference.

BUjTVHM50wlxfuxUpHDcOQ.text: Good Burritos - what more can I sayWe got given a free taster of Tacos in the street and felt the need to go and try the food as a result - and it was good - very much like a mexican Subway in the way they have a system where you can add things to your burrito as you go down the line of servers. so yeah good stuff but i'm no expert in this

b4apafxoriLqUOWrLHz-7A.text: When one is in London good Mexican food is not what comes immediately to mind. Well, here's a definite exception to that line of thinking. This restaurant, located in London's trendy Islington/Angel district, makes a great burrito. Ours were tasty as well as being ample.  The establishment was clean and the service was prompt and very friendly. John Taitt took care of our order and is an excellent ambassador for Chilango. If you're ever in this area of London and have a taste for a burrito, look no further than Chilango. You will leave with a smile on your face.

GUIlmOr_eZ5zIN4anCtmHA.text: I'll say this about Chilango, they're growing their customer base the 'right' way. I've had positive interactions with their staff - including serving me right at closing time - and online with their new twitter account (@chilango_uk).When you've got an itch for burritos, Chilango will scratch it.

5BO-9KFFOUAhs9Z2mYvBRg.text: After all the hype and reviews I couldn't just walk on past now could I. I stopped in here for a quick snack and a beer before a gig one night and was suitably impressed.Just on the evidence of my chips and guac, I knew we were dealing some decent nosh. I was impressed by the layout, the staff and the feel to the place. So much so that I stopped in at their Fleet St branch during a lunch break to see what all the fuss was about. The hype is justified.

6sAzz3iwSNAprB2iQdHKzA.text: I've been going here on-and-off for a few months now, and I just can't seem to get enough of their Carnitas...soo good. Like many Mexican restaurants, it's a cantine-style affair, where you order your food at a bar and then find somewhere to sit (or take it away).The food, on the whole, I think is pretty excellent. There are a few things I'd try to stay away from (their Margaritas look disgusting --though I've never been brave enough to try one). As Kristen M. mentioned, they have really amazing Guacamole. I can't fault their food at all really, it's fantastic.However, siding with the other voters here, the décor really is somewhat offensive. I don't think I need to detail why (everyone else has that pretty much covered), but suffice to say this is why my review isn't a 5-star. But hey, it's not exactly pricy!

TgHRIzBHZrUR6eUdlp92sg.text: Having moved here from the US 3.5 years ago, I have found myself missing Chipotle. This place is the closest thing I have found. I'm a huge fan of Chilango - GREAT quality food, good service. All around a win-win!PS - the BEST guac I've found in London and I dare say, best I've ever had. Trust me.

dMj6jJSVm0fWVGz_X2Xuig.text: Are you hungry and in a hurry?  Want to grab a quick bite on your way home to take back to your place?  Want something that won't break your pocket book? Don't want to deal with crabby or unfriendly service? Then Chilango may be for you.  I wasn't overly impressed by my chicken burrito, but it wasn't horrid either.  It didn't have alot of taste to it, but I didn't spit it out either. It made me miss my Qudoba take out back in Seattle.  If you are familiar with Qudoba's tex mex food chain, then I would say this place is definitely not as good.  The guacamole was actually good, you pay extra for it which is standard at any place like this.  They had some fresh made corn chips that looked good, but I didn't try those as the burrito appeared large enough to fill my belly up real good.  They mentioned everywhere on posters that they were rated Zagat survey 2011 and 2012 No. 1 Mexican restaurant.  I don't think I would agree with that.  But then, I am not familiar with what the other London options are.

j8KsF7ANhcBy6pgXSfVt7w.text: The steak burrito was pretty nice but the wrap it was on was way too flouery..pretty muc just dough! also the staff were a bit rude!!

TOBVaVrGa3-RMvYnY308Xw.text: I'm not a big fan of chains and am pretty skeptical about Mexican food in London, but Chilango does a decent job. Their guac is bomb (although you don't get much for your money when you get it added to your taco/burrito, and the meat is pretty well-prepared. Flavors aren't amazing, but they're pretty darn good.

hrBviLvSQXvVJuI9t4TV1g.text: Chilango is in my opinion one of the best burrito places in London, and I really enjoy their shrimp version which makes it stand out in comparison to Chipotle and Tortilla (which must be their main competitors in this market). However Chilango is a lot nicer when it comes to all their fillings and is pretty much on level with what I have had on the other side of the Atlantic. Price wise Chilango is comparable with it's two main competitors here in London, which means it isn't exactly super cheap.Only minus with this place would be that if you come relatively late they might be out of shrimps, or guacamole (which happens at Chipotle too). The place itself is very nice in Upper Street and the decor and split-level with a round stair-case, (fire-fighter style) makes it look pretty cool.

NaBDMGtDi0xgzNHTo1-mhQ.text: A craze for burritos is sweeping through London town. 2010 may have been the year of the underground burrito (albeit with numerous front page articles about how underground and unknown it all was) but 2011 is the year when the masses will gobble up burritos like they were kebabs. Anyway, my burrito order: Chicken please (cheapest at just below £7), salsa, no guacamole(yuck) and both cheese and sour cream (of course). Wrapped up and plonked rather unceremoniously into a paper lined plastic basket, it didn't stun me with its size, as I was expecting from other's comments. However, once I started unwrapping my prize from its foil coverings I realised why it was known as a beast. Almost too big to fit my mouth around, I think it may well be impossible to eat without making a mess. But if you can ignore the rice and beans landing on your dry clean only dress at regular intervals, then the burrito itself isn't too bad. But, when the focus is on devouring food without causing some kind of structural fault to occur, the foods flavour itself becomes a sideshow.  I went for the mildest option, which hopefully explains the lack of strong flavour from any part of the burrito. The chicken was nice, as were the beans. The tortilla was warm and moist. In all it was very nice. Nice of course, being a word which damns with faint praise. It hasn't put me off burritos for life, but, combined with a rather steep price for what is essentially a wrap wrapped in foil, I wouldn't make the journey to Upper Street purely for it. I have been since to the new Chancery Lane Chilangos, and had a steak burrito, which was better, but I still don't think it's worth the price.

4gtyTjIkwEjVAacnfg-VPg.text: It's like a Subway - except the food actually tastes fresh and they sell Jose Cuervo margerita slushes! The burritos are huge and very tasty - with meat and spice intensity options on offer. However if you're low on pennies, watch out, they charge an extra £1 for guacamole...

B81ilm5CGB_3H_JZGaXQ1A.text: For someone who doesn't really like Mexican or spicey food in general, the beef, chili bean and cheese burrito I tried was delicious. Really clean tasting and full of flavour. I would definately go there again to get my hands on another.And i really liked the decore of the place, fun, fresh and funky, fitting in nicely to the surroundings of Angel.
